Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDI-Type II: VolcanoSRI: 4D Volcano Tomography in a Large-Scale Sensor Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create a new paradigm, VolcanoSRI (Volcano Seismic Realtime Imaging), for imaging 4D (four-dimensional) tomography of an active volcano in real-time. VolcanoSRI is a large-scale sensor network of low-cost geophysical stations that analyzes seismic signals and computes real-time, full-scale, three-dimensional fluid dynamics of the volcano conduit system within the active network. The computed 4D tomography model will illuminate complex, time-varying dynamics of an erupting volcano, providing a deeper scientific understanding of volcanic processes, as well as a basis for rapid detection of volcanic hazards. VolcanoSRI will potentially make the fictional holographic projector known as Virgil in the film "Supervolcano" a reality.

Realizing the VolcanoSRI system requires a transformative study on the science of complex volcano systems and the design of large-scale sensor networks. Our approach integrates innovations on distributed tomographic algorithms, collaborative signal processing, and situation-aware networking technology for large-scale real-time sensor systems. The distributed tomography algorithm disperses the computational burden to the sensor nodes and performs real-time tomographic inversion within the network. Such an approach has never been attempted before and represents a major achievement for both earth and computer science. The team is composed of computer and earth scientists including early pioneers of wireless sensor networks as applied to volcano monitoring.

VolcanoSRI holds vast potential for real-time risk monitoring and development of early-warning systems for volcanoes and other earth hazards. The new approach taken in VolcanoSRI is general, and can be implemented as a new network paradigm for other sensor-network applications, including oil-field exploration and structural and biomedical-health monitoring. The educational activities of this project include enhancing undergraduate and graduate curriculum and research programs at the three collaborating universities. Through this project, we plan to broaden access to these course materials by providing the course lectures, all readings, and assignments online to the public. This project provides many opportunities for collaborations of students across earth and computer science, increasing involvement of women and minorities, at the three collaborating universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project creates a new paradigm, Real-time In-situ Subsurface Imaging (RISI), for imaging 3D subsurface structures and dynamics in real-time within a computational sensor network. RISI is a technology milestone toward the full invention of "subsurface camera and video camera" in our vision. The subsurface imaging process today involves massive data collection from hundreds and thousands of sensors to a central place, then post processing and computing. The whole process is expensive and often takes days even months to complete. This project takes a sharp departure from the aforementioned traditional paradigm: instead of data collection then computing, this project designs a computational sensor network that is capable of sensing and processing seismic signals, and computing 3D subsurface image in-situ in real-time. The RISI system proposed here has never been attempted before and represents a milestone for both earth and computer science efforts. Multiple innovative distributed seismic imaging algorithms have been successfully developed and validated using both synthetic and real-world seismic data set. The hardware prototype system has also been implemented and can be extended as a general field instrumentation platform, to incorporate new geophysical data processing and computing algorithms, beyond seismic. The RISI system holds vast potential for real-time risk monitoring and development of early-warning systems for volcanoes and other earth hazards, and for reducing the costs and risks of E&P and mitigating the environment concerns.

The methodology of RISI system also has broader impact far beyond the subsurface imaging and in fact opens a new computing paradigm called fog computing. The fog computing approach taken in RISI syetm is general, and can be implemented as a new computing paradigm for many other IoT or cyber-physical systems applications, including oil-field exploration, structural and biomedical-health monitoring and smart grid. A patent has been filed and received much attention from the energy industry. The technology transfer is under active exploration and the team was invited to participate in the NSF iCorps program, and received the Best Entreprenuer Lead award. This project also enhances undergraduate and graduate curriculum and research programs. Minority students, including several female graduate students, have participated in this project. Multiple graduate students and postdocs were trained through this project and two dozens peer-reviewed publications were disseminated to the broader science and engineering community.
